>> Think back on the ways you've probably
used water today already. Apart from cooking

5.text:
or mopping the floors, think about how you
used water to care for your personal body.

11.text:
I'd like to share with you how I used water
already. I got a drink of water when I first

16.text:
got up this morning. I used water to cleanse
my toothbrush, to brush my teeth, and to rinse

23.text:
out my mouth. I used lots of water to shower
with and to wash my hair. Then I used water

30.text:
in the sink to shave my face and a little
bit to smooth back my hair. When I went to

36.text:
the toilet, it was water that carried away
the waste down a tube somewhere far out of

41.text:
sight and out of mind. And then after the
toilet, I washed my hands with soap in the

47.text:
sink. Water is necessary in each of these
instances to either replenish my body with

53.text:
fluids, to wash away the wastes from my body,
or to keep my body free from germs--these

59.text:
three categories of health, sanitation, and
hygiene. Water is also used for cosmetic purposes

67.text:
when I shave or wet my hair to keep it in
place.

70.text:
In fact, regarding health, men need to consume
about 3.7 liters a day, or about a gallon

78.text:
of water, and women need to consume about
three quarters of a gallon. About 70-75% of

84.text:
our human body weight is water. The blood
is 82% water, human brain is 85% water. And

92.text:
it is no wonder that some of the early symptoms
of dehydration are fuzzy short-term memory,

97.text:
trouble with basic math, or difficulty in
focusing on small print because your eyes

103.text:
use a lot of fluids to do their work. What
does water do in and for the body, we should

110.text:
ask. Well, it serves as lubricant. It forms
the base for saliva. It forms fluid that surrounds

117.text:
the joints. It regulates the body temperature,
for example, through perspiration. It helps

123.text:
to alleviate constipation by moving food through
the intestinal tract and eliminating waste

129.text:
products, so it's a very fine detox agent.
And finally, it regulates metabolism, that

136.text:
is, how our body gets energy from its food.
So our thirst is a natural signal to our body

142.text:
that it needs water. And when people don't
get enough clean water to drink, they will

148.text:
drink the only other water they can get, dirty
water.

153.text:
Water is used to do two things regarding sanitation:
to dilute the waste and to move it to a place

158.text:
where it can be treated. For many centuries
before there were very many people on the

163.text:
planet, human and animal body, bodily waste
could be released into a river or stream.

169.text:
When the waste is sufficiently small, the
water has enough volume to dilute the waste

175.text:
and render it harmless to people who might
be living downstream. The world and the amount

181.text:
of water it contains has and will forever
be the same. It will not increase. But as

188.text:
populations have increased, it has become
much more difficult to find enough water to

193.text:
dilute waste sufficiently. This is especially
true in the industrial or developed world

199.text:
with people moving into larger and larger
cities, as you heard during the last lecture

207.text:
Well, this brings us to the second usage of
water in sanitation: to carry it away to a

213.text:
place for it to be treated or disposed of.
A very old system still in use today is called

219.text:
the septic tank and system. The water carries
the waste by gravity from the home to an enclosed

226.text:
tank. There the solids will settle to the
bottom, and the liquid water flows out the

231.text:
top of the tank into a drain field where it
percolates into the soil. There natural bacteria

237.text:
in the waste and in the soil have time to
degrade the waste and make it more inert or

243.text:
safe. Septic systems can be very effective
ways of using water to transport wastes, but

250.text:
only in places where population densities
are small and there is plenty of land for

255.text:
the water to be spread out. A more modern
system and one that's used in large developed

261.text:
cities is one in which water is used to carry
the waste to a centrally located waste treatment

268.text:
plant or called a wastewater treatment plant.
And there in the treatment plant natural processes

277.text:
are mimicked using engineered systems, in
effect, doing the same thing that the bacteria

283.text:
would do in nature in that soil that we spoke
about, but in a more controlled and speedier

289.text:
fashion. Then once treated, that water can
be rereleased into a river or a lake or a

295.text:
stream where it will not have an adverse affect
on either ecology of the water body or people

303.text:
The third important category is hygiene. It
refers to those practices that we do to maintain

308.text:
and preserve our health. Specifically, hygiene
in the home and everyday life settings plays

314.text:
an important part in preventing the spread
of infectious diseases. Now many of these

319.text:
practices require water: hand washing, as
we've mentioned, hand washing in the sink,

325.text:
proper rinsing of food, care and cleaning
of domestic animals, and other practices that

331.text:
are generally considered proper hygiene, including
bathing regularly, washing scalp hair, keeping

338.text:
hair short, wearing clean clothing, and brushing
one's teeth. Some practices are even gender

344.text:
specific, such as those used by a woman during
her menstrual cycle. Hand washing is probably

350.text:
the most important single behavior that can
be implemented in a developing country to

355.text:
reduce the risk of infectious diseases. Recall
how every hospital has numerous hand washing

361.text:
stations throughout the patient care floors
and visitors are required to wash their hands

367.text:
before entering a patient's room. Let's take
a look at what is often called the F diagram.

373.text:
The F diagram shows various pathways that
pathogenic or disease-causing bacteria can

380.text:
take from feces to future victim—that is,
you or me. The fecal material if it is not

387.text:
deposited in an isolated place such as latrine
or toilet can easily find its way into water,

394.text:
into fields where crops are grown, or fingers
of children who are playing. Finally, flies

400.text:
often carry bacteria from the feces to your
food, which is why we often cover our food.

406.text:
Some of these pathways lead directly to your
mouth, as when you drink contaminated water

410.text:
or touch your dirty fingers to your mouth,
or they lead to your food, which of course

416.text:
leads to your mouth. Once in your mouth, you
are at increased risk for the diseases that

422.text:
these pathogenic bacteria will carry. It has
been estimated that almost 1/10 of the global

429.text:
disease burden, the total global disease burden,
could be prevented by improving water supply,

435.text:
sanitation, hygiene, and management of water
resources. That's all diseases. Childhood

443.text:
underweight causes about 35% of all deaths
of children under the age of five. An estimated

449.text:
50% of this underweight or malnutrition is
associated with repeated diarrhea or intestinal

456.text:
nematode infections as a result of unsafe
water. Such underweight in children is directly

462.text:
responsible for about 70,000 deaths per year.
But we'll talk more about these diseases in
